Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Nanosensors for rapid detection of food pathogens
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to improve food safety and reduce the incidents caused by food-borne pathogens. This project will: (i) help ensure that the U.S. food supply is safe by providing food facilities and consumers with effective diagnostics tools, (ii) advance the commercialization of a portable food monitor, and (iii) provide timely protection against consumer microbial hazards and eliminate unnecessary product recalls. This sensor will directly benefit society by providing a new diagnostic tool that may empower users to take control of the safety of the food they consume.

This I-Corps project will further develop a biosensor technology that functions via a synergy between conducting poly (amic) acid (PAA) and metal nanoparticles. Nano-sized nanoparticles have a high electron affinity and can strip off electrons from the surrounding PAA matrix. The technology is designed to detect the 'notorious five' pathogens namely, Salmonella, E. coli, Norovirus, Staphylococcus epidermidis and Listeria (Sensal) all within 5 minutes at 5 colonies forming unit/mL or less. Unlike enzymes, DNA or lipids, the recognition ligands are more robust and specific for the pathogen. The biosensor device is similar to a glucose strip. When samples containing the pathogens are exposed to the strip, concentration-dependent recognition results in visible color change on the membrane strips indicating positive results for E.coli or other pathogens.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Binghamton
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this iCorps project is to advance the commercialization of a portable, user-friendly device capable of rapid detection of multiple pathogenic bacteria. The device, known as “Triple Five (5-5-5 Sensal)” is equipped with polymeric membrane strips consisting of adhesion and recognition ligands with the processing capabilities of a smartphone. Triple Five (5-5-5 Sensal) captures and rapidly identifies the “notorious five” pathogens: Salmonella, E. coli, Norovirus, Staphylococcus epidermidis and Listeria (Sensal) within 5 minutes at a limit of detection (LOD) 5 colonies forming unit/mL or less. The entire device is about 7 by 6 by 5 centimeters in size. These iCorps teams choose a customer segment from the Food Processing's annual list of the top 100 food and beverage companies in the United States and Canada and embarked on a customer discovery phase. During this phase, the team gained a better understanding of the needs in markets such as food processing, manufacturing and handling sectors. The scope of the project also involved designing a more affordable solution for individual consumers at a projected cost of $75. The projected outcome of this project was a customer-discovery, guided transition of the Triple Five (5-5-5 Sensal) from the laboratory to the marketplace.  

 

Key Outcomes

  • Conducted 241 customer discovery interviews
  • Discovered that the customers interviewed were not currently a viable target market for our product. Most customers agreed that accurate and rapid pathogen testing is important, however they do not have control over which tests the company performs or how those tests are performed. The majority of the customers interviewed were not concerned about improving pathogen detection technique since the current solutions offered did not negatively impact their jobs. A key conclusion to this experience is that in order for our pathogen sensor to become a marketable product, we must change our business model and either target new customer segments or change our detection from pathogens to another harmful substance (for example, allergens, toxins or fungus).
  • Created a small business concern called VeillTech (www.veiltech.com)
  • VeillTech was established in 2017 after a successful NSF-Innovation Corps Customer Discovery experience. It currently has two full time and two part time technical research staff.  The research staff has expertise in synthetic chemistry, microbial assay developments, electrical engineering, and mathematics.
  • Lessons learned video posted on YouTube for future cohorts to view (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2rrdt2WX3TU)
  • Attended at the Upstate New York (UNY) I-Corps Node Conference on Monday, June 5, 2017 from 11:00 AM to 3:00 PM EDT at the Syracuse Center of Excellence (CoE), room 203 (second floor), 727 East Washington Street, Syracuse, NY 13244. All three members of our team were present to share our experience.
  • Attended a short I-CORPS course at Binghamton University, Binghamton, NY to share our

Modified by: Omowunmi A Sadik
